elements.content: A twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional iron coordination polymer with PtS-type topology, Fe (NCS)2(TINM)•1/2TINM (1, TINM = tetrakis­(isonicotinoxymethyl)­methane), constructed by a semirigid tetradentate ligand, displays an incomplete spin-crossover behavior with T 1/2 at 118 K. Furthermore, the correlation between the external-pressure and spin transition is also discussed following theoretical approaches.
elements.clean_text: A twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional iron coordination polymer with PtS-type topology, Fe (NCS)2(TINM)⋅1/2TINM (1, TINM = tetrakis(isonicotinoxymethyl)methane), constructed by a semirigid tetradentate ligand, displays an incomplete spin-crossover behavior with T 1/2 at 118 K. Furthermore, the correlation between the external-pressure and spin transition is also discussed following theoretical approaches.

elements.content: A three-dimensional iron coordination polymer displays an incomplete spin-crossover behavior with T 1/2 at 118 K. The correlation between the external-pressure and spin transition is also discussed following theoretical approaches.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional iron coordination polymer displays an incomplete spin-crossover behavior with T 1/2 at 118 K. The correlation between the external-pressure and spin transition is also discussed following theoretical approaches.

elements.content: The phenomenon of spin-crossover (SCO) between high-spin (HS) and low-spin (LS) states of 3d4-3d7 transition metal ions has sparked great substantive discussions in the field of coordination chemistry during the past decades. The electronically active SCO complexes (commonly octahedral Fe­(II) and Fe­(III) complexes) could behave as bistable materials, whose structure, color, optical, or magnetic properties can be dramatically changed by external stimuli such as thermal, pressure, and magnetic-field switching and light irradiation. Hence, SCO complexes could be of desirable function materials for their potential applications as nanoswitches, micromemory devices, and medicinal diagnostics.
elements.clean_text: The phenomenon of spin-crossover (SCO) between high-spin (HS) and low-spin (LS) states of 3d4-3d7 transition metal ions has sparked great substantive discussions in the field of coordination chemistry during the past decades. The electronically active SCO complexes (commonly octahedral Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes) could behave as bistable materials, whose structure, color, optical, or magnetic properties can be dramatically changed by external stimuli such as thermal, pressure, and magnetic-field switching and light irradiation. Hence, SCO complexes could be of desirable function materials for their potential applications as nanoswitches, micromemory devices, and medicinal diagnostics.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs), as one class of prominent functional materials, are ever-increasing in their degree of structural diversity and tunability as well as their wide range of physical and chemical properties. As the intersection of two important research fields between SCO iron complexes and high-dimensional CPs, SCO CPs have been attracting more and more attention due to their fascinating magnetic properties and response to versatile external stimuli. The isolated SCO active centers could be directly interconnected by proper linking ligands to form the extended systems, which is very important to improve the cooperativity or synergistic effect compared to oligonuclear ones. Further, supramolecular or polymeric networks not only include various short- and long-range interactions, but exhibit intriguing properties such as modularity, selectivity, and reversibly absorbability or desorbability.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers (CPs), as one class of prominent functional materials, are ever-increasing in their degree of structural diversity and tunability as well as their wide range of physical and chemical properties. As the intersection of two important research fields between SCO iron complexes and high-dimensional CPs, SCO CPs have been attracting more and more attention due to their fascinating magnetic properties and response to versatile external stimuli. The isolated SCO active centers could be directly interconnected by proper linking ligands to form the extended systems, which is very important to improve the cooperativity or synergistic effect compared to oligonuclear ones. Further, supramolecular or polymeric networks not only include various short- and long-range interactions, but exhibit intriguing properties such as modularity, selectivity, and reversibly absorbability or desorbability.

elements.content: However, the assembly of high-dimensional coordination networks usually depends on many factors, and directly obtaining the anticipated structure of topologies still poses a great challenge. In this regard, proper design and selection of organic linkers with modifiable backbone and high connectivity would be a facile route to modulate novel network topologies with anticipated properties. The incorporation of multidentate ligands has been verified to promote the formation of 3-dimensional geometry, and several 3-D coordination frameworks with fascinating SCO properties have been constructed by utilizing bidentate and tridentate N-ligands. Hence, we are committed to search flexible multidentate bridging ligands to enrich the scanty toolbox of SCO CPs, which are inclined to be the optimal functional materials that combine the advantages of structural diversity of CPs and electronic switching capability of SCO complexes together.
elements.clean_text: However, the assembly of high-dimensional coordination networks usually depends on many factors, and directly obtaining the anticipated structure of topologies still poses a great challenge. In this regard, proper design and selection of organic linkers with modifiable backbone and high connectivity would be a facile route to modulate novel network topologies with anticipated properties. The incorporation of multidentate ligands has been verified to promote the formation of 3-dimensional geometry, and several 3-D coordination frameworks with fascinating SCO properties have been constructed by utilizing bidentate and tridentate N-ligands. Hence, we are committed to search flexible multidentate bridging ligands to enrich the scanty toolbox of SCO CPs, which are inclined to be the optimal functional materials that combine the advantages of structural diversity of CPs and electronic switching capability of SCO complexes together.

elements.content: The semirigid dendritic tetradentate ligand TINM, inherently adopts a highly distorted tetrahedral disposition of the four pyridyl groups, each of which could connect a distinct metal atom, which could be seen as an ideal candidate for the self-assembly of the higher-dimensional SCO CPs. In addition, topological analysis has been identified as a useful tool for understanding the intricate structure of CPs, and lots of topological configurations such as NbO, NiAs, and PtS have been reported. The PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of tetrahedral and square-planar shapes, has been discussed thoroughly before, but seldom with SCO identities. Herein, we present the synthesis, fascinating architecture, and magnetic characterization of the 3-D iron complex formulated as Fe­(NCS)2(TINM)•1/2TINM (1) with twofold interpenetrated PtS topology.
elements.clean_text: The semirigid dendritic tetradentate ligand TINM, inherently adopts a highly distorted tetrahedral disposition of the four pyridyl groups, each of which could connect a distinct metal atom, which could be seen as an ideal candidate for the self-assembly of the higher-dimensional SCO CPs. In addition, topological analysis has been identified as a useful tool for understanding the intricate structure of CPs, and lots of topological configurations such as NbO, NiAs, and PtS  have been reported. The PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of tetrahedral and square-planar shapes, has been discussed thoroughly before, but seldom with SCO identities. Herein, we present the synthesis, fascinating architecture, and magnetic characterization of the 3-D iron complex formulated as Fe(NCS)2(TINM)⋅1/2TINM (1) with twofold interpenetrated PtS topology.

elements.content: The glittering red crystal aggregates formed on the wall of the test tube by the solvent diffusion method after 2 or 3 days. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1 were collected at 106 and 250 K. An ORTEP drawing (250 K) of the basic unit is shown in . Crystal 1 adapts the tetragonal P4­(2)/n space group and its asymmetric unit contains one distinct FeII atom, two SCN– groups (N3, N3D), and a half of the bridging TINM ligand (N1, N2); additionally, a quarter of TINM is discrete. The FeII ion is located in octahedral coordination geometry formed with four N atoms from four TINM ligands in equatorial direction and the other two are occupied by SCN– group of axial position. The equatorial bond length [Fe–N1B = Fe–N1C = 2.238 Å­(106 K), 2.258 Å (250 K), Fe–N2 = Fe–N2A = 2.221 Å­(106 K), 2.252 Å (250 K)] are longer than those of the axial positions [Fe–N3 = Fe–N3A = 2.081 Å (106 K), 2.071 Å (250 K)]. The average change of the equatorial and axial bond distances at different temperatures is 0.02 and 0.01 Å, respectively, which is indistinctive compared with the alteration of 0.15–0.2 Å in typical FeII SCO compounds. Consistent with the spin transition behavior of iron complex, incomplete SCO behavior could be observed in the entire temperature region. At ambient pressure, about 35% high-spin centers have transferred to the low-spin state. Therefore, only a little difference in bond lengths between high- and low-temperature regions could be detected due to the mean bond length of all iron centers.
elements.clean_text: The glittering red crystal aggregates formed on the wall of the test tube by the solvent diffusion method after 2 or 3 days. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1 were collected at 106 and 250 K. An ORTEP drawing (250 K) of the basic unit is shown in . Crystal 1 adapts the tetragonal P4(2)/n space group and its asymmetric unit contains one distinct FeII atom, two SCN- groups (N3, N3D), and a half of the bridging TINM ligand (N1, N2); additionally, a quarter of TINM is discrete. The FeII ion is located in octahedral coordination geometry formed with four N atoms from four TINM ligands in equatorial direction and the other two are occupied by SCN- group of axial position. The equatorial bond length [Fe-N1B = Fe-N1C = 2.238 Å(106 K), 2.258 Å (250 K), Fe-N2 = Fe-N2A = 2.221 Å(106 K), 2.252 Å (250 K)] are longer than those of the axial positions [Fe-N3 = Fe-N3A = 2.081 Å (106 K), 2.071 Å (250 K)]. The average change of the equatorial and axial bond distances at different temperatures is 0.02 and 0.01 Å, respectively, which is indistinctive compared with the alteration of 0.15-0.2 Å in typical FeII SCO compounds. Consistent with the spin transition behavior of iron complex, incomplete SCO behavior could be observed in the entire temperature region. At ambient pressure, about 35% high-spin centers have transferred to the low-spin state. Therefore, only a little difference in bond lengths between high- and low-temperature regions could be detected due to the mean bond length of all iron centers.

elements.content: ORTEP drawing of the structure of 1 with atom labels. Symmetry operations: (A) 1/2 – x, 3/2 – y, z; (B) 2 – y, 1/2 + x, −1/2 + z; (C) −1/2 + y, 1 – x, −1/2 + z;(D) 3/2 – x, 3/2 – y, z; (E) 1/2 – x, 1/2 – y, z; (F) y, 1/2 – x, 1/2 – z; (G) 1/2 – y, x, 1/2 – z.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP drawing of the structure of 1 with atom labels. Symmetry operations: (A) 1/2 - x, 3/2 - y, z; (B) 2 - y, 1/2 + x, -1/2 + z; (C) -1/2 + y, 1 - x, -1/2 + z;(D) 3/2 - x, 3/2 - y, z; (E) 1/2 - x, 1/2 - y, z; (F) y, 1/2 - x, 1/2 - z; (G) 1/2 - y, x, 1/2 - z.

elements.content: If the four-connected FeII centers with the four equatorial nitrogen atoms and the tetra-topic ligands are regarded as square units and tetrahedral units (formed by the four methylenes connected to the quaternary carbon center) (a,b), respectively, the whole structure of 1 can be simply viewed as a decorated PtS topology, shown in c. However, due to the twisted configuration of the semirigid pyridyl arms, the whole framework is not a perfect PtS-type framework, whose tetrahedral units directly distort compared to the prototype (d). Further, a twofold interpenetrated framework resulted from the arrangement of the two identical PtS-type networks, which possess channels along the crystallographic a and b axes in the structure (e). However, these cavities are occupied by the uncoordinated TINM ligands. The trapping of the uncoordinated ligands into the twofold interpenetrated framework was attributed to the weak interactions between the components of the geometry and their preferable accommodation to the framework. For example, there are strong interactions as S···π and hydrogen bonding interaction between the discrete ligand and the sulfur atom of SCN– group, and C–C···π and C–H···π interactions between the pyridyl rings of the trapped and coordinated ligands. As shown in Figure S4 and Table S3, hydrogen bonds between uncoordinated oxygen atoms and hydrogen atoms of the methylene group/pyridyl rings were found with the distance of [O1···H23B = 2.378 Å­(106 K), 2.399 Å (250 K), O1···H20A = 2.792 Å­(106 K), 2.723 Å (250 K), O6···H8A = 2.820 Å­(106 K), 2.979 Å (250 K)]. Calculations of the whole structure showed the percentage of the void to be about 9%, indicating the possibility that some solvent molecules are captured in the solid state, which could be further confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (shown in the Supporting Information). About 6.10% weight loss may be attributed to the release of two MeOH molecules up to ∼70 °C (with ca. 5.98%).
elements.clean_text: If the four-connected FeII centers with the four equatorial nitrogen atoms and the tetra-topic ligands are regarded as square units and tetrahedral units (formed by the four methylenes connected to the quaternary carbon center) (a,b), respectively, the whole structure of 1 can be simply viewed as a decorated PtS topology, shown in c. However, due to the twisted configuration of the semirigid pyridyl arms, the whole framework is not a perfect PtS-type framework, whose tetrahedral units directly distort compared to the prototype (d). Further, a twofold interpenetrated framework resulted from the arrangement of the two identical PtS-type networks, which possess channels along the crystallographic a and b axes in the structure (e). However, these cavities are occupied by the uncoordinated TINM ligands. The trapping of the uncoordinated ligands into the twofold interpenetrated framework was attributed to the weak interactions between the components of the geometry and their preferable accommodation to the framework. For example, there are strong interactions as S⋅⋅⋅π and hydrogen bonding interaction between the discrete ligand and the sulfur atom of SCN- group, and C-C⋅⋅⋅π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the pyridyl rings of the trapped and coordinated ligands. As shown in Figure S4 and Table S3, hydrogen bonds between uncoordinated oxygen atoms and hydrogen atoms of the methylene group/pyridyl rings were found with the distance of [O1⋅⋅⋅H23B = 2.378 Å(106 K), 2.399 Å (250 K), O1⋅⋅⋅H20A = 2.792 Å(106 K), 2.723 Å (250 K), O6⋅⋅⋅H8A = 2.820 Å(106 K), 2.979 Å (250 K)]. Calculations of the whole structure showed the percentage of the void to be about 9%, indicating the possibility that some solvent molecules are captured in the solid state, which could be further confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (shown in the Supporting Information). About 6.10% weight loss may be attributed to the release of two MeOH molecules up to ~70 °C (with ca. 5.98%).

elements.content: Square (a) and tetrahedral (b) building blocks constructed the three-dimensional PtS-type structure of 1 (c). Augmented PtS net (d). Interpenetrated topology of 1 along with discrete tetra-dentate ligand (e).
elements.clean_text: 2  Square (a) and tetrahedral (b) building blocks constructed the three-dimensional PtS-type structure of 1 (c). Augmented PtS net (d). Interpenetrated topology of 1 along with discrete tetra-dentate ligand (e).

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1 at different pressures with an applied field of 5 kOe over the 2–300 K range were presented in , which also confirmed the SCO characterization of 1. Under normal pressure, the χM T value is 4.22 cm3 K mol–1 at room temperature, corresponding to the values of HS state for iron­(II), slightly larger than the common values of HS state for iron­(II), which could be ascribed to the unstable solvent molecules and spin–orbital coupling of iron centers. Upon cooling, χM T value remains almost constant down to 170 K, and then decreases gradually until a new plateau from 60 to 17.5 K. The χM T value is 2.26 cm3 K mol–1 at 17.5 K, indicating the incomplete SCO behavior of 1. Calculated from the χM T value, almost half of the iron active centers had been triggered to occur the spin transition from HS state to LS one. The sharp decrease of χM T values below 17.5 K should be ascribed to zero-field splitting of the remaining HS-FeII centers. No obvious hysteresis phenomenon could be observed during cooling and warming processes. Plenty of investigations have revealed that the spin transition is sensitive to external pressure with the changed molecule size and volume during this process. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored by utilizing the crystal sample immersed in silicon oil as pressure transmitting medium. As expected, the χM T value gradually decreases with the increasing external pressure, while T c moves upward to the higher temperature region. The parameters and plot of transition temperature T 1/2 under different external pressures in the cooling mode are listed in and shown in (inset). By utilizing mean field theory, two parts of good linear dependence of T 1/2 and P were observed when the external pressure was below 7 Kbar and above 7 Kbar, respectively. The presentation of two different linear curves would to some extent reflect the mechanism and effect of applied external pressure to SCO behavior in the 3D framework. At the beginning, applying external pressure mainly causes the volume contraction because of the fluffy packing structure of 1. When the applied pressure exceeds 7 Kbar, the pressure effect tends to not only cause the successive volume contraction, but also change the strength of the crystal field around the FeII center, which causes higher slope compared to the low pressure region.

Under normal pressure, the χM T value is 4.22 cm3 K mol-1 at room temperature, corresponding to the values of HS state for iron(II), slightly larger than the common values of HS state for iron(II), which could be ascribed to the unstable solvent molecules and spin-orbital coupling of iron centers. Upon cooling, χM T value remains almost constant down to 170 K, and then decreases gradually until a new plateau from 60 to 17.5 K. The χM T value is 2.26 cm3 K mol-1 at 17.5 K, indicating the incomplete SCO behavior of 1. Calculated from the χM T value, almost half of the iron active centers had been triggered to occur the spin transition from HS state to LS one. The sharp decrease of χM T values below 17.5 K should be ascribed to zero-field splitting of the remaining HS-FeII centers. No obvious hysteresis phenomenon could be observed during cooling and warming processes. Plenty of investigations have revealed that the spin transition is sensitive to external pressure with the changed molecule size and volume during this process. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored by utilizing the crystal sample immersed in silicon oil as pressure transmitting medium. As expected, the χM T value gradually decreases with the increasing external pressure, while T c moves upward to the higher temperature region. The parameters and plot of transition temperature T 1/2 under different external pressures in the cooling mode are listed in  and shown in  (inset). By utilizing mean field theory, two parts of good linear dependence of T 1/2 and P were observed when the external pressure was below 7 Kbar and above 7 Kbar, respectively. The presentation of two different linear curves would to some extent reflect the mechanism and effect of applied external pressure to SCO behavior in the 3D framework. At the beginning, applying external pressure mainly causes the volume contraction because of the fluffy packing structure of 1. When the applied pressure exceeds 7 Kbar, the pressure effect tends to not only cause the successive volume contraction, but also change the strength of the crystal field around the FeII center, which causes higher slope compared to the low pressure region.

In addition, the incomplete SCO behaviors of 1 under variable external pressure could also be ascribed to the “internal pressure effect” originating from the huge and slightly clumsy body of quadridentate ligand and host–guest repulsion. Larger guest molecules, TINM ligands, would support greater suppression in the LS state compared to the HS state, and possess less extended configuration in the smaller pores of LS state, which totally tend to stabilize HS state over LS state. Therefore, even when high external pressure up to 10 kbar had been applied onto the samples, only 75% HS irons transfer to the LS state. Moreover, the ΔH and ΔS under different external pressures have been simulated according to the Van’t Hoff equation (Figure S7, Table S2). As shown in Figure S7, the nonlinear tendency of ΔH and ΔS versus external pressure could be observed. These values became larger along with the external increase, especially in the high pressure region. It was well-known that the values of ΔH and ΔS would become larger along with the increasing pressure. However, the tendency is tender, and different from the phenomenon for 1, which was caused by the incomplete transition behavior. The primary values of ΔH and ΔS were far smaller than the typical values of low pressure due to the low ratio of spin transition centers. These values became closer to the normal values observed for the complete spin transitions, due to the high ratio of spin transition centers. Regardless, the simulated values of ΔH and ΔS could also validate the obvious effect of external pressure to spin transition, which tends to favor low spin state and trigger the spin transition in the high temperature region.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the incomplete SCO behaviors of 1 under variable external pressure could also be ascribed to the "internal pressure effect" originating from the huge and slightly clumsy body of quadridentate ligand and host-guest repulsion. Larger guest molecules, TINM ligands, would support greater suppression in the LS state compared to the HS state, and possess less extended configuration in the smaller pores of LS state, which totally tend to stabilize HS state over LS state. Therefore, even when high external pressure up to 10 kbar had been applied onto the samples, only 75% HS irons transfer to the LS state. Moreover, the ΔH and ΔS under different external pressures have been simulated according to the Van't Hoff equation (Figure S7, Table S2). As shown in Figure S7, the nonlinear tendency of ΔH and ΔS versus external pressure could be observed. These values became larger along with the external increase, especially in the high pressure region. It was well-known that the values of ΔH and ΔS would become larger along with the increasing pressure. However, the tendency is tender, and different from the phenomenon for 1, which was caused by the incomplete transition behavior. The primary values of ΔH and ΔS were far smaller than the typical values of low pressure due to the low ratio of spin transition centers. These values became closer to the normal values observed for the complete spin transitions, due to the high ratio of spin transition centers. Regardless, the simulated values of ΔH and ΔS could also validate the obvious effect of external pressure to spin transition, which tends to favor low spin state and trigger the spin transition in the high temperature region.

elements.content: In conclusion, we describe a twofold interpenetrated 3D CP with PtS-type network, which exhibits incomplete SCO behavior confirmed by variable-temperature crystal structures, and magnetic susceptibilities under variable external pressure. Thus, the architecture traps a large bulk of uncoordinated guest that occupies the space and stabilizes the whole framework. Further work searching for new 3-D SCO compounds which exhibit complete spin transition behavior and obvious hysteresis phenomenon is urgently needed and ongoing by us.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we describe a twofold interpenetrated 3D CP with PtS-type network, which exhibits incomplete SCO behavior confirmed by variable-temperature crystal structures, and magnetic susceptibilities under variable external pressure. Thus, the architecture traps a large bulk of uncoordinated guest that occupies the space and stabilizes the whole framework. Further work searching for new 3-D SCO compounds which exhibit complete spin transition behavior and obvious hysteresis phenomenon is urgently needed and ongoing by us.

cln_elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1 at different pressures with an applied field of 5 kOe over the 2–300 K range were presented in , which also confirmed the SCO characterization of 1. Under normal pressure, the χM T value is 4.22 cm3 K mol–1 at room temperature, corresponding to the values of HS state for iron­(II), slightly larger than the common values of HS state for iron­(II), which could be ascribed to the unstable solvent molecules and spin–orbital coupling of iron centers. Upon cooling, χM T value remains almost constant down to 170 K, and then decreases gradually until a new plateau from 60 to 17.5 K. The χM T value is 2.26 cm3 K mol–1 at 17.5 K, indicating the incomplete SCO behavior of 1. Calculated from the χM T value, almost half of the iron active centers had been triggered to occur the spin transition from HS state to LS one. The sharp decrease of χM T values below 17.5 K should be ascribed to zero-field splitting of the remaining HS-FeII centers. No obvious hysteresis phenomenon could be observed during cooling and warming processes. Plenty of investigations have revealed that the spin transition is sensitive to external pressure with the changed molecule size and volume during this process. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored by utilizing the crystal sample immersed in silicon oil as pressure transmitting medium. As expected, the χM T value gradually decreases with the increasing external pressure, while T c moves upward to the higher temperature region. The parameters and plot of transition temperature T 1/2 under different external pressures in the cooling mode are listed in and shown in (inset). By utilizing mean field theory, two parts of good linear dependence of T 1/2 and P were observed when the external pressure was below 7 Kbar and above 7 Kbar, respectively. The presentation of two different linear curves would to some extent reflect the mechanism and effect of applied external pressure to SCO behavior in the 3D framework. At the beginning, applying external pressure mainly causes the volume contraction because of the fluffy packing structure of 1. When the applied pressure exceeds 7 Kbar, the pressure effect tends to not only cause the successive volume contraction, but also change the strength of the crystal field around the FeII center, which causes higher slope compared to the low pressure region.

Upon cooling, χM T value remains almost constant down to 170 K, and then decreases gradually until a new plateau from 60 to 17.5 K. The χM T value is 2.26 cm3 K mol-1 at 17.5 K, indicating the incomplete SCO behavior of 1. Calculated from the χM T value, almost half of the iron active centers had been triggered to occur the spin transition from HS state to LS one. The sharp decrease of χM T values below 17.5 K should be ascribed to zero-field splitting of the remaining HS-FeII centers. No obvious hysteresis phenomenon could be observed during cooling and warming processes. Plenty of investigations have revealed that the spin transition is sensitive to external pressure with the changed molecule size and volume during this process. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored. Variable temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 under gradually increasing external pressure have also been monitored by utilizing the crystal sample immersed in silicon oil as pressure transmitting medium. As expected, the χM T value gradually decreases with the increasing external pressure, while T c moves upward to the higher temperature region. The parameters and plot of transition temperature T 1/2 under different external pressures in the cooling mode are listed in  and shown in  (inset). By utilizing mean field theory, two parts of good linear dependence of T 1/2 and P were observed when the external pressure was below 7 Kbar and above 7 Kbar, respectively. The presentation of two different linear curves would to some extent reflect the mechanism and effect of applied external pressure to SCO behavior in the 3D framework. At the beginning, applying external pressure mainly causes the volume contraction because of the fluffy packing structure of 1. When the applied pressure exceeds 7 Kbar, the pressure effect tends to not only cause the successive volume contraction, but also change the strength of the crystal field around the FeII center, which causes higher slope compared to the low pressure region.

metadata.title:
External Pressure Effect on a Twofold Interpenetrated
3D PtS-Type Spin-Crossover Coordination Polymer
